I always admire good intentions that good people have to save an animal, but unless it can't wait, calling a wildlife vet who can safely release the animal to free it is best. Antlers in their velvet stage have a blood supply and nerves which can feel pain when amputated. Cut the vine instead. Many thanks and God bless the kindness of rescuers to save!
As for fair, it is hardly a "fair fight" when a deer and any animal is scoped out many yards from their view, unawares that they are being targeted to be shot. And not perceiving a threat, owing to their genuine gentle and loving nature and that in a friendly, curious manner they have frequently walked right up to strangers, both human and animal, trusting to approach not expecting to be harmed- numerous videos have shown wild deer walking up to strangers to accept, befriend them and even to be pet. They don't seek people or anything to harm - and there's no real fight- just innocent helpless animals that have the right to defend themselves when threatened and their defense it to run away and escape, but if they can't because they are trapped, then it's not an option- thank God in His wisdom He taught them survival- everyone can understand that any animal in a vulnerable situation, injured, scared or threatened- not knowing the intentions of a particular person- whether that person means to rescue or harm them naturally may resist that person. That's not unusual. A video showed a rescuer determined to save a drowning dog and as he was being bit multiple times by the dog, he still continued to help him out. He sustained numerous bites with no injury to the dog. I was amazed that he didn't abort the rescue even after being repeatedly bitten. He knew that the dog was likely to respond that way because he was afraid that the man was going to harm him. Brave man and an amazing true story.

Every time I watch a rescue video of deers etc. by men, even though I'm grateful for their help, I want so bad to say to them: talk to the animal in a low, gentle tone to calm it down before you approach him/it & as you approach it. if you're within reach, then stroke gently whenever possible - I have rescued a few animals myself, I always do that & it works the same as it works for a pet: you earn their trust & they calm down. It's very important they don't stress, for their health as much as for the rescuer's safety. Animals aren't space aliens: they have feelings (fear/stress/aggression in such situation) and respond to your *energy*. Show a calm, gentle demeanor & win their trust, turn their energy into a calm, receptive disposition. This is not a critique, it's advice I hope someone will have the chance to implement and see how it helps you help the animals. :) Thank you for all your help and kind consideration and be blessed!

Also, the vast majority of hunters go by what we call the 'Rules of Fair Chase', which basically states that you give the animal a sporting chance to get away. Here in PA we don't hunt deer over bait piles, or use hounds to chase them because that violates the Fair Chase rules. (Not that I have an issue with people who do hunt legally over bait, it's just that it's illegal in PA.)

Because as hunters, we also understand the need to CONSERVE wildlife, not 'kill em all' the way many people seem to think that we are! The fees we pay for our licenses goes for conservation of wildlife and natural resources to make sure that they are there for future generations.
